Expectation1: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation1: A cruising aircraft simply requests the routine altimeter setting.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I glance at my watch, heart pounding. My shift as an air traffic controller is supposed to end in ten minutes, but I’m still at the polling station, inching forward in a line that barely moves. My phone buzzes—my relief is running late, and I’m still technically on call. Suddenly, an official calls out, “Voters with last names A through M, please move to the new line!” My last name starts with B. The new line is longer, but the official’s voice is firm. I know I’m expected to follow instructions, but every minute here is a minute I’m not at my post, ready to communicate with pilots. Just then, a message comes through: a cruising aircraft is requesting the routine altimeter setting. I’m supposed to be there, headset on, providing clear instructions. My duty to the pilots is clear, but so is my responsibility as a voter to follow the rules. I feel the pressure mounting, torn between the demands of the skies and the demands of democracy, my mind racing as I stand at the crossroads of my two roles.
